description.value: Alerts are used to display important messages inline or as toast notifications.
A component for displaying animated GIFs and WEBPs that play and pause on interaction.
Animate elements declaratively with nearly 100 baked-in presets, or roll your own with custom keyframes.
Avatars are used to represent a person or object.
Badges are used to draw attention and display statuses or counts.
Breadcrumb Items are used inside breadcrumbs to represent different links.
Breadcrumbs provide a group of links so users can easily navigate a website's hierarchy.
Buttons represent actions that are available to the user.

Use the variant attribute to set the button’s variant. Variants can be Filled, Outline and Text Buttons. Use the outline attribute to draw outlined buttons with transparent backgrounds. Use the text variant to create text buttons that share the same size as regular buttons but don’t have backgrounds or borders.
Use the size attribute to change a button’s size.

It’s often helpful to have a button that works like a link. This is possible by setting the href attribute, which will make the component render an <a> under the hood. This gives you all the default link behavior the browser provides (e.g. CMD/CTRL/SHIFT + CLICK) and exposes the target and download attributes.
As expected, buttons can be given a custom width by setting the width attribute. This is useful for making buttons span the full width of their container on smaller screens.
Use the prefix and suffix slots to add icons.
Use the caret attribute to add a dropdown indicator when a button will trigger a dropdown, menu, or popover.

Use the loading attribute to make a button busy. The width will remain the same as before, preventing adjacent elements from moving around. Clicks will be suppressed until the loading state is removed.
Use the disabled attribute to disable a button.
The focus event gives the user feedback that the Button has been focused by the keyboard interaction and that the button component is ready for use.
Button groups can be used to group related buttons into sections.
Cards can be used to group related subjects in a container.
A carousel item represent a slide within a carousel.
Carousels display an arbitrary number of content slides along a horizontal or vertical axis.
Checkboxes allow the user to toggle an option on or off.
Use the checked attribute to activate the checkbox.
Use the indeterminate attribute to make the checkbox indeterminate.
The focus event gives the user feedback that the Checkbox has been focused by the keyboard interaction.
Use the disabled attribute to disable the checkbox.
Use the size attribute to change a checkbox’s size.
The invalid status is used to warn the user that the Checkbox is invalid. For example, if the check is mandatory and nothing has been checked.

Use the setCustomValidity() method to set a custom validation message. This will prevent the form from submitting and make the browser display the error message you provide. To clear the error, call this function with an empty string.
Color pickers allow the user to select a color.
Copies data to the clipboard when the user clicks the button.
Details show a brief summary and expand to show additional content.
Dialogs, sometimes called "modals", appear above the page and require the user's immediate attention.
Dividers are used to visually separate or group elements.
Drawers slide in from a container to expose additional options and information.
Dropdowns expose additional content that "drops down" in a panel.
Formats a number as a human readable bytes value.
Formats a date/time using the specified locale and options.
Formats a number using the specified locale and options.

Icons buttons are simple, icon-only buttons that can be used for actions and in toolbars.

For a full list of icons that come bundled with Synergy, refer to the Assets.
Use the size attribute to change a icon-button size.
Use the disabled attribute to disable the icon button.
The focus event gives the user feedback that the icon-button has been focused by the keyboard interaction.
The Icon button can have two color variants, Primary or Neutral Color.
Icons are symbols that can be used to represent various options within an application.
Compare visual differences between similar photos with a sliding panel.
Includes give you the power to embed external HTML files into the page.
Inputs collect data from the user.
Use the label attribute to give the input an accessible label. For labels that contain HTML, use the label slot instead.
Add descriptive help text to an input with the help-text attribute. For help texts that contain HTML, use the help-text slot instead.
Use the placeholder attribute to add a placeholder.
Add the clearable attribute to add a clear button when the input has content.
Add the password-toggle attribute to add a toggle button that will show the password when activated.
Add the read-only attribute to draw a read-only input.
Use the disabled attribute to disable an input.
Use the size attribute to change an input's size.
Use the prefix and suffix slots to add icons.
The focus attribute provides feedback to the users, informing them that the input component is ready for use.

The invalid status is used to warn the user that the input is invalid. For example, if the entry of text is mandatory and nothing has been entered or if a text has been entered that does not have the correct format.
Menu items provide options for the user to pick from in a menu.
Menu labels are used to describe a group of menu items.
Menus provide a list of options for the user to choose from.
The Mutation Observer component offers a thin, declarative interface to the MutationObserver API.
Options define the selectable items within various form controls such as select.
Popup is a utility that lets you declaratively anchor "popup" containers to another element.
Progress bars are used to show the status of an ongoing operation.
Progress rings are used to show the progress of a determinate operation in a circular fashion.
Generates a QR code and renders it using the Canvas API.
Radios buttons allow the user to select a single option from a group using a button-like control.
Radio groups are used to group multiple radios or radio buttons so they function as a single form control.
Add descriptive help text to a radio group with the help-text attribute. For help texts that contain HTML, use the help-text slot instead.
Radios and radio buttons can be disabled by adding the disabled attribute to the respective options inside the radio group.
The size of Radios and Radio Buttons will be determined by the Radio Group’s size attribute.
Setting the required attribute to make selecting an option mandatory. If a value has not been selected, it will prevent the form from submitting and display an error message.

Use the setCustomValidity() method to set a custom validation message. This will prevent the form from submitting and make the browser display the error message you provide. To clear the error, call this function with an empty string.
The focus event gives the user feedback that one of the Checkboxes has been focused by the keyboard interaction.
The invalid status is used to warn the user that the Radio Group is invalid. For example, if the radio is mandatory and nothing has been checked.
Ranges allow the user to select a single value within a given range using a slider.
Ratings give users a way to quickly view and provide feedback.
Outputs a localized time phrase relative to the current date and time.
The Resize Observer component offers a thin, declarative interface to the ResizeObserver API.
Selects allow you to choose items from a menu of predefined options.
Skeletons are used to provide a visual representation of where content will eventually be drawn.
Spinners are used to show the progress of an indeterminate operation.
Split panels display two adjacent panels, allowing the user to reposition them.
Switches allow the user to toggle an option on or off.
Use the checked attribute to activate the switch.
Use the disabled attribute to disable the switch.
Use the size attribute to change a switch’s size.
The focus event gives the user feedback that the Switch has been focused by the keyboard interaction.
Tab groups organize content into a container that shows one section at a time.
Tab panels are used inside tab groups to display tabbed content.
Tabs are used inside tab groups to represent and activate tab panels.
Tags are used as labels to organize things or to indicate a selection.
Use the size attribute to change a tab’s size.
Use the removable attribute to add a remove button to the tag.
Textareas collect data from the user and allow multiple lines of text.
Use the label attribute to give the textarea an accessible label. For labels that contain HTML, use the label slot instead.
Add descriptive help text to a textarea with the help-text attribute. For help texts that contain HTML, use the help-text slot instead.
Use the rows attribute to change the number of text rows that get shown.
Use the placeholder attribute to add a placeholder.
Add the read-only attribute to draw a read-only textarea.
Use the disabled attribute to disable a textarea.
Use the size attribute to change a textarea’s size.
By default, textareas can be resized vertically by the user. To prevent resizing, set the resize attribute to none.
Textareas will automatically resize to expand to fit their content when resize is set to auto.
The focus event gives the user feedback that the Textarea has been focused by the keyboard interaction and that the Textarea component is ready for use.

The invalid status is used to warn the user that the input is invalid. For example, if the entry of text is mandatory and nothing has been entered or if a text has been entered that does not have the correct format.
Tooltips display additional information based on a specific action.
A tree item serves as a hierarchical node that lives inside a tree.
Trees allow you to display a hierarchical list of selectable tree items. Items with children can be expanded and collapsed as desired by the user.
The visually hidden utility makes content accessible to assistive devices without displaying it on the screen.
Radios allow the user to select a single option from a group. \nRadios are designed to be used with radio groups.
The focus event gives the user feedback that the Radio has been focused by the keyboard interaction.
Use the disabled attribute to disable a radio.
Add the size attribute to the Radio Group to change the radios’ size.
The invalid status is used to warn the user that the Radio is invalid. For example, if the radio is mandatory and nothing has been checked.
To set the initial value and checked state, use the value attribute on the containing radio group.
Tips for using Essential in your Angular app.
Tips for using Essential in your React app.
Tips for using Essential in your Vue 2 app.
Tips for using Essential in your Vue 3 app.
Learn how to customize Essential through parts and custom properties.
Some things to note about Essential and forms.
Choose the installation method that works best for you.
Discover how to localize Essential with minimal effort.
Everything you need to know about theming Essential.
Learn more about using custom elements.
Essential recognizes the need for all users to have undeterred access to the websites and applications that are created with it.
Changes to each version of the project are documented here.
Essential has a growing community of designers and developers that are building amazing things with web components.
Essential is an open source project, meaning everyone can use it and contribute to its development.
Border radius tokens are used to give sharp edges a more subtle, rounded effect.
Color tokens help maintain consistent use of color throughout your app.
Elevation tokens are used to give elements the appearance of being raised off the page.
Additional design tokens can be found here.
Spacing tokens are used to provide consistent spacing between content in your app.
Transition tokens are used to provide consistent transitions throughout your app.
Typography tokens are used to maintain a consistent set of font styles throughout your app.
Z-indexes are used to stack components in a logical manner.
This page explains how to integrate Essential with a Laravel app.
This page explains how to integrate Essential with a NextJS app.
This page explains how to integrate Essential with a Rails app.
